message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Event-Based Finite-Time Control for Nonlinear Multiagent Systems With Asymptotic Tracking
Paper Abstract: In this article, an adaptive neural finite-time event-triggered consensus tracking problem is studied for nonlinear multiagent systems (MASs) under directed graphs. First, the unknown nonlinear functions of MASs can be approximated by neural networks. Then, a distributed adaptive event-triggered control scheme is proposed via command filter and backstepping technique. The newly designed control scheme cannot only circumvent the problem of the explosion of complexity, but also remove the singularity issue typical of conventional backstepping technique. In the meanwhile, an event-triggered mechanism with a dynamic threshold is devised to reduce the waste of network resources. Moreover, by using a novel finite-time stability criterion, it can be proved that the closed-loop system is finite-time stable and the consensus tracking errors can reach zero as time approaches to infinity. Finally, a numerical example is given to validate the feasibility of the proposed scheme.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

The search results mention event-triggered control in the context of academic research. Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at the Eindhoven University of Technology, was named Fellow of the IEEE in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

However, the search results don't provide a detailed technical definition or explanation of event-triggered control itself. The results primarily focus on related concepts like:

- **Event-driven programming** and **event-driven architecture**, which are broader software design paradigms where systems respond to events
- **Time-triggered systems**, which execute tasks according to a predetermined schedule (as opposed to event-triggered systems)

Event-triggered control appears to be a specialized field within control theory that deals with systems that respond to specific events rather than operating on fixed time schedules. To get more detailed technical information about event-triggered control principles, applications, or methodologies, you might want to search for academic papers or more specialized resources in control engineering.

## Consensus Dynamics in Multi-Agent Systems

Consensus dynamics, also known as agreement dynamics, is an area of research at the intersection of systems theory and graph theory that studies how a group of agents—such as robots, sensors, or decision-makers—interacting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange.(no content)The goal of the consensus problem in multi-agent systems is to ensure that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity, despite starting with potentially different initial values.

## Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.

## Computer Science Applications

In the broader context of distributed computing, real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.(no content)The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants of it such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems and are typically synchronous, dependent on an elected leader to make progress, and tolerate only crashes and not Byzantine failures.

Here's what I found about multiagent systems:

## Definition

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems have several important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Intelligence and Communication

Intelligence may include methodic, functional, procedural approaches, algorithmic search or reinforcement learning.(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement, with example languages being Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Backpressure routing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpressure_routing"},{"title":"Anti-lock braking system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-lock_braking_system"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

## Search Results for Backstepping Control

Here's what I found about backstepping control:

### Definition and Purpose

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

### How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

### Application Context

Backstepping, along with feedback linearization and sliding mode control, are techniques that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory for controlling nonlinear systems.

### Historical Development

Petar V. Kokotovic made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Backstepping is particularly useful for controlling complex nonlinear systems by breaking down the control design problem into manageable, recursive steps.

Links: [{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network"},{"title":"Neural network (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(biology)"},{"title":"History of artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Energy-based generative neural network","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy-based_generative_neural_network"},{"title":"Convolutional neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convolutional_neural_network"},{"title":"Physical neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physical_neural_network"},{"title":"Mathematics of neural networks in machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematics_of_neural_networks_in_machine_learning"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_neural_network"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of neural networks based on the search results:

## What Are Neural Networks?

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, a neural network is an artificial mathematical model used to approximate nonlinear functions.

## Structure and Architecture

Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).(no content)A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.(no content)The behavior of the network depends on the strengths (or weights) of the connections between neurons. A network is trained by modifying these weights through empirical risk minimization or backpropagation in order to fit some preexisting dataset.

## Applications

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

## Training and Learning

They can learn from experience, and can derive conclusions from a complex and seemingly unrelated set of information.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

## Notable Types

Different specialized neural networks exist, including convolutional neural networks (CNN), a type of feedforward neural network that learns features via filter (or kernel) optimization, and graph neural networks (GNN), which are specialized artificial neural networks that are designed for tasks whose inputs are graphs.

Links: [{"title":"Directed graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_graph"},{"title":"Force-directed graph drawing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force-directed_graph_drawing"},{"title":"Directed acyclic graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Directed_acyclic_graph"},{"title":"Category talk:Directed acyclic graphs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_talk:Directed_acyclic_graphs"},{"title":"Graph (discrete mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_(discrete_mathematics)"},{"title":"Graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory"},{"title":"DOT (graph description language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOT_(graph_description_language)"},{"title":"Topological sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_sorting"},{"title":"Minimum cut - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_cut"},{"title":"Eulerian path - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eulerian_path"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about directed graphs:

## Definition

A directed graph (or digraph) is a graph that is made up of a set of vertices connected by directed edges, often called arcs.(no content)In formal terms, a directed graph is an ordered pair G = (V, A) where V is a set whose elements are called vertices, nodes, or points; and A is a set of ordered pairs of vertices, called arcs, directed edges, arrows, or directed lines.

## Key Differences from Undirected Graphs

It differs from an ordinary or undirected graph, in that the latter is defined in terms of unordered pairs of vertices.(no content)A distinction is made between undirected graphs, where edges link two vertices symmetrically, and directed graphs, where edges link two vertices asymmetrically.

## Types of Directed Graphs

Several important variations exist:
- A directed graph is acyclic if it has no directed cycles, and the usual name for such a digraph is directed acyclic graph (DAG).
- Weighted directed graphs (also known as directed networks) are (simple) directed graphs with weights assigned to their arrows.

## Real-World Applications

The link structure of a website can be represented by a directed graph, in which the vertices represent web pages and directed edges represent links from one page to another.(no content)DAGs have numerous scientific and computational applications, ranging from biology (evolution, family trees, epidemiology) to information science (citation networks) to computation (scheduling).

Web search results for query: "nonlinear systems control"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Zero dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero_dynamics"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"}]

I've completed a web search for "nonlinear systems control." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Differences from Linear Control

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle. Unlike linear systems, the mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Analysis and Design Techniques

These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Notable Control Strategies

Some important techniques include:
- Feedback linearization is a common strategy employed in nonlinear control to control nonlinear systems.
- Nonlinear model predictive control, or NMPC, is a variant of model predictive control that is characterized by the use of nonlinear system models in the prediction.
- Input-to-state stability (ISS) is a stability notion widely used to study stability of nonlinear control systems with external inputs.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)It applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Differences from Linear Control

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle. Unlike linear systems, the mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Analysis and Design Techniques

These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Notable Control Strategies

Some important techniques include:
- Feedback linearization is a common strategy employed in nonlinear control to control nonlinear systems.
- Nonlinear model predictive control, or NMPC, is a variant of model predictive control that is characterized by the use of nonlinear system models in the prediction.
- Input-to-state stability (ISS) is a stability notion widely used to study stability of nonlinear control systems with external inputs.

I've completed a web search for "adaptive control systems." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain. For instance, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## How It Works

Adaptive control uses on-line identification of the process parameters, or modification of controller gains, thereby obtaining strong robustness properties.(no content)Thefoundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification.

## Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Historical Application

Adaptive controls were applied for the first time in the aerospace industry in the 1950s, and have found particular success in that field.

## Real-World Examples

Adaptive control systems are used in various practical applications, including:
- Adaptive traffic control systems, which are traffic management strategies in which traffic signal timing changes, or adapts, based on actual traffic demand.
- Adaptive cruise control (ACC), which is a type of advanced driver-assistance system for road vehicles that automatically adjusts the vehicle speed to maintain a safe distance from vehicles ahead.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
